name: Stoic Wisdom
description: Timeless philosophy from Marcus Aurelius, Seneca, and Epictetus to guide your life.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: You have power over your mind - not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
quotes.notes: Verified from 'Meditations' (Ta eis heauton). This is a modern translation; the original Greek expresses the Stoic concept of the dichotomy of control.

quotes.content: We suffer more often in imagination than in reality.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's epistolary work 'Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium.' The Latin reads 'plura sunt quae nos terrent quam quae premunt.'

quotes.content: It's not what happens to you, but how you react to it that matters.
quotes.notes: Paraphrased from the Enchiridion (Handbook). The original discusses how we are disturbed not by things but by our judgments about things.

quotes.content: The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
quotes.notes: Modern translation from Meditations. Various translations exist; some render 'thoughts' as 'soul' or 'mind.'

quotes.content: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
quotes.notes: From 'De Providentia' where Seneca discusses why misfortunes befall good people and how adversity builds character.

quotes.content: Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. This passage reflects Marcus' practical approach to virtue over philosophical debate.

quotes.content: He who fears death will never do anything worthy of a living man.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's letters discussing the Stoic approach to mortality and living fully without fear of death.

quotes.content: First say to yourself what you would be; and then do what you have to do.
quotes.notes: From Epictetus' teachings recorded by his student Arrian. Emphasizes the Stoic practice of setting intentions and acting accordingly.

quotes.content: The soul becomes dyed with the color of its thoughts.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. One of Marcus' most poetic expressions of how habitual thinking shapes character.

quotes.content: No man is free who is not master of himself.
quotes.notes: Core Stoic teaching on inner freedom. Epictetus, himself a former slave, emphasized that true freedom comes from self-mastery.

quotes.content: Begin at once to live, and count each separate day as a separate life.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's letters on the urgency of living well. Reflects the Stoic practice of treating each day as complete in itself.

quotes.content: Very little is needed to make a happy life; it is all within yourself, in your way of thinking.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. Expresses the Stoic view that contentment depends on internal attitude rather than external circumstances.

quotes.content: Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants.
quotes.notes: Reflects Epictetus' teaching on the simplicity of needs. Consistent with Stoic minimalism and focus on inner wealth.

quotes.content: It is not that we have a short time to live, but that we waste a lot of it.
quotes.source: On the Shortness of Life (c. 49 CE)
quotes.notes: Opening argument of 'De Brevitate Vitae.' Seneca's famous essay on time management and living purposefully.

quotes.content: Accept the things to which fate binds you, and love the people with whom fate brings you together.
quotes.notes: From Meditations. Expresses the Stoic concept of amor fati (love of fate) and acceptance of one's circumstances.

quotes.content: Man is not worried by real problems so much as by his imagined anxieties about real problems.
quotes.notes: Paraphrased from the Enchiridion. Central to Stoic cognitive therapy - distinguishing between events and our judgments about them.

quotes.content: Luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity.
quotes.notes: Often attributed to Seneca but the exact source is uncertain. The sentiment aligns with Stoic views on preparation and seizing moments.

quotes.content: Never let the future disturb you. You will meet it with the same weapons of reason.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. Addresses anxiety about the future with the Stoic confidence in rational thinking.

quotes.content: There is nothing so unfortunate that we cannot find something to console ourselves for having it.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's correspondence with Lucilius. Illustrates the Stoic practice of finding perspective in adversity.

quotes.content: Make the best use of what is in your power, and take the rest as it happens.
quotes.notes: Core teaching of the dichotomy of control - focus on what you can control and accept what you cannot.

quotes.content: The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. Reflects the Stoic emphasis on independent thinking over popular opinion.

quotes.content: True happiness is to enjoy the present, without anxious dependence upon the future.
quotes.notes: From early letters to Lucilius on achieving tranquility through present-moment focus.

quotes.content: If you are distressed by anything external, the pain is not due to the thing itself, but to your estimate of it.
quotes.notes: Central Stoic principle verified from Meditations. The basis of ancient cognitive behavioral approaches.

quotes.content: He suffers more than necessary, who suffers before it is necessary.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's letters on anticipatory anxiety. The Stoic cure for worry about future events.

quotes.content: Any person capable of angering you becomes your master.
quotes.notes: Paraphrased from the Enchiridion. Illustrates how emotional reactions give others power over us.

quotes.content: When you arise in the morning, think of what a precious privilege it is to be alive.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. Part of Marcus' morning contemplation practice to cultivate gratitude.

quotes.content: Associate with people who are likely to improve you.
quotes.notes: From Seneca's advice on choosing companions wisely. The Stoic view that character is influenced by those around us.

quotes.content: Don't explain your philosophy. Embody it.
quotes.notes: Paraphrased from Discourses. Epictetus emphasized that philosophy is a way of life, not just theoretical discussion.

quotes.content: How much time he gains who does not look to see what his neighbor says or does or thinks.
quotes.notes: Verified from Meditations. On focusing on one's own conduct rather than judging others.

quotes.content: Life is long if you know how to use it.
quotes.source: On the Shortness of Life (c. 49 CE)
quotes.notes: Core thesis of 'De Brevitate Vitae.' Seneca argues that life is ample for those who spend it wisely.
